results.title: My Hometown – Munro Melano
results.brief_description: When he was just 17-years old, drummer Leon Isackson started capturing his life on the road from 1959 onwards with these clips – shot on 8MM film – combined to capture a nostalgic period of Australian music and form the video for Munro Melano’s ‘My Hometown ‘ (2014).

constellations_primary.name: My Hometown: Archives woven into new narrative
constellations_primary.description: Offering viewers a snapshot of life on the road for an Australian touring band in the 1960s, 'My Hometown', directed by Sari Braithwaite was developed reimagining archival 8mm footage shot by drummer Leon Isackson.

results.description: Leon Isackson is considered one of Australia’s greatest drummers, having played with everyone from John Farnham to Johnny O’Keefe and Little Pattie. When he was just 17-years-old, he started capturing his life on the road as a touring musician for six years from 1959 onwards with these clips – shot on 8MM film – combined to capture a nostalgic period of Australian music and form the video for Munro Melano’s ‘My Hometown’.
description_for_label: Leon Isackson is considered one of Australia’s greatest drummers, having played with everyone from John Farnham to Johnny O’Keefe and Little Pattie. When he was just 17-years-old, he started capturing his life on the road as a touring musician for six years from 1959 onwards with these clips – shot on 8MM film – combined to capture a nostalgic period of Australian music and form the video for Munro Melano’s ‘My Hometown’.

results.title: My home my prison
results.creator_credit: Film Arts Foundation, Susana Blaustein Munoz and Erica Marcus
results.brief_description: The Palestinian journalist, Raymonda Hawa Tawil, has been a prominent Palestinian activist since the 1960s. For her commitment to Palestinian self-rule she has been arrested several times by the Israeli authorities and now lives in exile in Paris. But her equally passionate commitment to feminism and to questioning the role of violence and masculinity in Arab culture has meant that she has been a controversial figure for many Palestinian activists. Based on her autobiography, also called “My Home, My Prison”, this documentary examines the history of the Israeli Occupation and details the often humiliating experiences suffered by Palestinians living in the Occupied Territories. Compassionate and with a keen sense of justice, Tawil believes that no peace is possible until the Jews and Arabs commence a dialogue not predicated on fear or hate. “My Home, My Prison” is an exhilerating film made by two Jewish women who were inspired to investigate her life after reading her work.

results.title: My happiest years
results.creator_credit: Thames Television, Kevin Brownlow and David Gill
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Unknown Chaplin”.
The first of a trilogy throwing new light on Chaplin’s career in films. This part covers the period in which he made twelve 2 reel comedies. Using footage selected from previously uncut rushes, the progression of Chaplin’s ideas is uncovered and insight is given into his working methods. Narrated by James Mason. Rated: G

results.title: My grandson Lew
results.brief_description: Adapted from the book of the same title by Charlotte Zolotow. The story of a six year old boy who disturbed by recurring memories of his grandfather whom he has not seen for some years, discovers from his mother that his grandfather died some time ago. Highlights the fact that emotions experienced alone can be shared with others who have had similar experiences. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: My Grandmother ironed the King's shirts
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, David Verrall, Marcy Page, Lars Tommerbakke and Torill Kove
results.brief_description: Torill Kove’s grandmother often told her stories, one of which revolved around ironing shirts for the King of Norway. What if that intriguing detail was just the tip of the iceberg? Perhaps she also worked covertly in the Norwegian resistance - maybe she even spearheaded a campaign to create an unprecedented brand of guerrilla warfare. Treating history as a fabric woven from personal stories, animator Torill Kove follows a thread of family history, embroidering it with playful twists along the way. In ‘My Grandmother Ironed the King’s Shirts’ she imaginatively renders her grandmother’s life and work in Oslo, especially during World War II. Sharp and whimsical, her story combines the grandmother’s tales with historical events and fantasy and shows how a cherished anecdote can come to acquire a mythical status. This is remarkable story about an ordinary woman with a revolutionary instinct. With sharp humor it explores storytelling, myth-making and the important contributions that are possible through the most humble means. (Awards: Vancouver; Oscar nomination, Hollywood.) Narrated by Mag Ruffman.

results.title: My friends call me Tony
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Yuki Yoshida, Kathleen Shannon and Beverly Shaffer
results.brief_description: The film is about a ten-year-old boy who can distinguish only light from shadow. Despite this difficulty, he leads a very active life. The film shows how Tony Rossi manages his life. Awards: Lausanne; Los Angeles.

results.title: My friend Hans from Germany
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “My Friend”.
Tells something of the life of Hans, a German boy living in the village of Garmisch-Partenkirchen near Munich in Bavaria. Shows the harvest season and the unusual tradition of sheltering cattle under houses. Throughout the year Hans goes skiing on the nearby Zugspitz Mountain.

results.title: My Friend Flicka
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Ralph Dietrich and Harold Schuster
results.brief_description: A young boy is determined to befriend a rebellious horse in this touching family film based on the celebrated novel by Mary O’Hara. Setting his heart on winning Flicka’s confidence and ultimately taming her, Ken begins to grow up a little and everyone learns some important lessons in this poignant tale of love, patience, faith and ‘hope beyond hope’. Stars Roddy McDowall and Preston Foster.
